conclusion: Determine the voltage across conductor rod MN and direction of induced current through resistor R.
Setup involves a moving conductor in a magnetic field inducing an emf.
Two parallel guide-rails ab and cd separated by distance l.
Conductor rod MN placed perpendicularly on rails moving with constant velocity v.
System in uniform magnetic field B directed into the plane of the paper.
Resistor R connected between points b and d.
When a conductor moves in a magnetic field, an emf is induced across its ends.
Induced emf is given by formula: emf = B * l * v.
Voltage across conductor MN is equal to induced emf: U = B * l * v.
Use right-hand rule to determine direction of induced current.
Induced current flows from M to N in rod MN.
Current flows from M to N, then through rail cd to d, through resistor R from d to b, and back to M via rail ab.
Direction of induced current through resistor R is from d to b.
Final answer: Voltage across MN is U = B * l * v; direction of induced current through R is from d to b.
